Name: Nach Paris: Ultra Fast WWI Rules
Description:
Nach Paris is the Small War set of rules for World War I ground combat.

Covers all weapons systems including artillery and tanks.

The Two Page Rules series features rules that are 2 pages long with one combat card that has the information needed to play the game. The sequence of movement is decided by a dice roll and after that, the games follow the sequence of move-fire-move-fire. Casualties are decided simply and effectively. Morale is divided into 4 stages with the chance to rally at each stage. New players should be able to conduct their own transactions by the third move. These are combat rules that reflect the tactics and technologies of their era. Decisions are made by players, not cards or dice. These rules can be used for nearly any scale of the figure. They are great for large or small battles.

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Two Page Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Quick Panzer: Ultra Fast WWII Rules
Description:
Quick Panzer is the Small War rules set for World War II.

Infantry weapons, artillery mortars, antitank guns and over 100 different models of armored vehicles are all covered.

The actual rules are 2 pages long but the rules come with several annexes for those who want a lot of detail.

The Two Page Rules series features rules that are 2 pages long with one combat card that has the information needed to play the game. The sequence of movement is decided by a dice roll and after that, the games follow the sequence of move-fire-move-fire. Casualties are decided simply and effectively. Morale is divided into 4 stages with the chance to rally at each stage. New players should be able to conduct their own transactions by the third move. These are combat rules that reflect the tactics and technologies of their era. Decisions are made by players, not cards or dice. These rules can be used for nearly any scale of the figure. They are great for large or small battles.

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Two Page Rules (Small War Games)

Name: The Lucky Penny Diner
Description:
Hey, thanks for picking up a shift or two! It's been busy; guests have been coming at all hours of the day and night to warm their frozen feet and fill up on fries, burgers, and our famous fruit pies. As you can see there are no tables, just the row of barstools there. Guests are everyone's responsibility. We don't split tips here - the person who's served a guest the most food will get everything. Pay attention to what they like, and they'll tip well. Well, I think that's it... go talk to Gus in the back and he'll get you an apron and paper hat. Welcome aboard!

In The Lucky Penny Diner players are the waitstaff in a 24-hour diner, serving orders to guests, and trying to collect the most in tips. Cards are drafted into players' hands, then served to guests by laying the cards in an overlapping fashion beside them, representing how full they are getting.

What you serve, when, and to whom factor into how well you are rewarded. Do you serve dessert to a guest that your opponent is waiting on so that they can't serve them any more apps or entrees? Do you give it to the guy at the end to turn his two courses into three? Or do you serve it to the girl with the sweet tooth who will tip more for it?

—description from the designer

Name: Undying Lands
Description:
Putting the ‘reality’ back into your fantasy games

Welcome to Undying Lands a completely revised version of FLD. The constant evolution of the rules is thanks to the feedback I have received. Before I briefly cover the new features of the rules I would like to firstly focus on why these rules came about. The purpose and intent of this game is to provide players with a much more realistic fantasy game in contrast to the artificially  contrived contemporary games that pay little attention to deployment, command control, light troops, orders, linear tactics and ignore the problems of movement, drill  and  reserves,  they  have  unrealistic  armies  with  ultra  powerful beast that trance anything that moves, with 20 year old game mechanics repackaged every 5 years and sold at a phenomanal price that spotty teenagers are all to pleased to pay. Crap game, slick marketing. The list goes ever on.

We take the works of Tolkien and Moorcock to be actual historical accounts. In our careful reading we found that fantasy battle is an extension of the mechanics of historical battle. In Undying Lands you get all the tactical subtleties of historical wargaming plus an array of  fantastic beasts, sorcery, special attributes and their associated benefits and problems. Whether your intent is fair or foul, regardless of your Balrog  bodyguard, the ‘ordinary’ rank and file is the tactically most  important  soldier  on  your  battlefield  and  that  his  physical constraints is on par with his historical counterpart.

What’s  new  in Undying Lands? Basing is much more integrated and flexible, The command control system has been streamlined and clarified, troop and weapon characteristics have been amalgamated into a single versatile and variable factor. The result is a streamlined, integrated and smooth game that plays faster.

First, we define the combat and manoeuvre characteristics of your troops, then deal with command, control and orders starting from the top  down.  Next we generate the battle  field,  then  the  sections  on the game turn, movement, combat, missile fire, results and victory conditions.  Finally,  there's  a  section on 'how to  win and common battlefield, tactical and organisational errors. HAVE FUN.

—description from the rulebook

Name: Орлеан: Собор (Orléans: Cathedral)
Description:
ÐžÑ€Ð»ÐµÐ°Ð½: Ð¡Ð¾Ð±Ð¾Ñ€ ("Orléans: Cathedral") is a level II promo Place Tile for Orléans.
Having this tile adds 1 to your development status for all purposes.

It was created specifically for the Russian edition of the base game. The prototype was The Cathedral of the Dormition (Uspenskiy sobor) in the Moscow Kremlin.

This was included as a part of Orléans: Promo Ortskarten N°2.

Name: The Icarus Investigation
Description:
Free Print and Play version.

The Space Shuttle PK100A crashed somewhere in Texas on the unmanned maiden flight (Project Icarus).
Your team will search the crash site for items scattered around. Move items to the Investigation hangar for further investigation.
Could the cause be a broken bolt in control system, located in tail? Or an electric fire in a wing? Find out... Score Prestige Points during investigation. It is kind of cooperative -   but the most effective team will win.

Main elements are the crash site board with items (cubes) scattered around. Items are moved to the Investigation hangar board

Assistant (meeples) activates items by card play.

Deck building.
Primary mechanism is deck build. It is essential to build your deck according to actual situation on boards. Situation change quickly during a game, with a final dramatic race. You must discard useless cards. Correct Evidence cards must be discarded to your Personal file Board for end game scoring.

—description from the designer

Name: BEVERAGE
Description:
You are the CEO of a drinking water company in a big country. The "I-Sports Festival" has been announced within this country, and a new stadium-building project has been established. You and other CEOs have signed a contract to contribute financially to the building the stadium and to put your company logos on it.

The CEOs have started a campaign to sell their products at a fair price in the developing market and to raise the profile of the company through a variety of corporate activities, aiming to become one of the most well-known companies in the country after the completion of the stadium.

BEVERAGE combines a worker-placement mechanism and a bidding system, with the game being partially inspired by Age of Steam and 18xx. The players are CEOs of various beverage companies. A new sports stadium is being built, and each CEO wants to get the stadium built and land the sponsorship rights. The progress of construction is the game clock.

Players decide on the price of their drinking water, which must be produced and shipped, taking into account market trends and other factors. Products will be judged by the market and bought based on their price! Each player then receives the revenue generated.

Starting with the first player who sold products, the company will use the funds earned to operate their company, including corporate activities to help to raise awareness of their company. However, the amount of tax to be paid by raising the level of awareness will gradually increase, and of course, it will be necessary to place the worker in charge of the chosen activity in the respective area in order to take the action.

In addition, the players who issued stock during the course of corporate activity gain additional capital and the merits of additional recognition at the time when dividends are paid. However, if dividends are not paid, the player will have a disadvantage that can greatly reduce the reputation.

Upon completion of the stadium, the companies' name recognition will be increased according to the amount of money invested in the stadium. The CEO of the most well-known company thanks to all these activities wins.

publisher's summary

Name: Entropia: the Outer Stars
Description:
Time goes by, and the universe is full of galaxies swirling around. So it happens that stars once out of reach are now dangerously close: in Entropia «The Outer Stars» you will master new powers, new abilities and new ways to win: will you take up the challenge these new stars are offering you?

Current Stage:
98% Ready to crowdfunding
45% Illustrations and Graphics

—description from the publisher

Name: Forged in Blood: Rules for Company Level Battles in the Late Renaissance
Description:
Forged in Blood' is a Big Skirmish wargame for the Pike and Shot period based on the Song of Blades engine. 
Play raids, ambushes and reconnaissance missions, foraging parties, baggage supply raids, and attacks on isolated outposts and vulnerable gun positions.

MID SCALE: an army is 60 to 70 single based figures;

SMALL AREA: a 4’x4’ or a 3’x3’ table;

CAMPAIGN GENERATOR: follow a chosen band through linked encounters;

TROOP CHARACTERISTICS: identify your units with historically meaningful descriptions;

CHARACTER TRAITS: import heroes from Flashing Steel or create them from scratch

RULES: for lighting fires, grenades, demolitions and more!

ARMY LISTS: sample lists with variations for early and late 30YW, Spanish, French, Early and Late Swedish, Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, Wallachian, Moldavian and Transylvanian, Ottoman, English Civil War, Covenanters, and Irish.

FULLY DESCRIBED SCENARIO: with full unit descriptions to give you a head start

QUICK REFERENCE SHEETS.

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Song of Blades and Heroes

Name: Clash!
Description:
CLASH ! is a Wargame system with figurines that acts as a bridge between players of level, experience and even fro different periods.

The player embodies his entire army and makes decisions for each officer. It does not emphasize combat formations and is easy to learn.

CLASH! is not intended to be used in competition as it leaves a bit of improvisation to the players. In several places, the rule proposes solutions only.

The game is played with figurines, grouped in constituted units. Each figurine represents a certain number of real men, therefore a unit can represent from a troop to a regiment or more, generally a company, a squadron or equivalent.

Army lists are available online

—description (extract) from the ruleset

English rules in progress / French rules v1.0

Name: 200 Years Army Lists
Description:
Army Lists for Two Hundred Years 5mm Wargames Rules 1700-1900. Including lists for the Marlburian Period, Great North War, 18th Century, Seven Years War, American War of Independence, Revolutionary Wars, Napoleonic Wars, India 1840-1850, Mexico, Crimean War, Mid 19th Century, American Civil War, Mexican War, Late 19th Century and British Colonial Wars.

These army lists are unusual in that they contain between 80 and 100 armies from the period 1700 – 1900. Virtually every army list is taken from a specific battle or campaign and is given at least a paragraph of background information – so, unlike other books of army lists, it is much more a compilation of historical research adapted to a specific set of rules. The contents page lists:

Marlburian period (5 Armies)
Great Northern War (2 Armies)
Seven Years War (6 Armies)
American War of Independence (3 Armies)
French Revolutionary Wars (4 Armies)
Napoleonic Wars (26 Armies)
Indian Campaign 1840-1850 (2 Armies)
Mexican American Wars (2 Armies)
Crimean (3 Armies)
Mid-19th Century (3 Armies including Garibaldi – Italian War of Independence)
ACW and Mexican Wars (9 Armies)
Late 19th Century (7 Armies including USA and Indian Wars)
British Colonial 1879-1890 (6 Armies including Zulu, Afghan & Mahdist)

The last two pages, 65 and 66, contain rule amendments and corrections.
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Cogbug
Description:
Cogbug is a mechanical gearboard tabletop game created in Estonia.
You have to PLACE cogwheels, SPIN gear systems and MOVE your bot minions the fastest across the field to your opponent’s base in order to win! 
But beware: the road to victory is not easy: the trails may not be straight and your opponents will do anything to stop you!

Name: Kotek i motylki
Description:
Gucio - black kitty - is missing. His trail leads us to the meadow. No wonder that the curious and mischievous kitty runs here among the grass, since there are so many wonderful butterflies around. There are so many of them that it seems impossible to count them all. Who of you will be smarter and more perceptive? Find out!

Kotek i motylki is a game that supports counting in a fun and emotional way. In addition, players must demonstrate perceptiveness and reflexes to indicate flower tokens with the correct result as soon as possible.

Purpose of the game: Players count the butterflies appearing on faceup Butterfly cards, and then seal the result token. With the correct calculations, they can get a card. The player with the most Butterfly cards at the end of the game wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Urodziny Tappiego
Description:
Do you know Viking Tappi? He has a long, red beard, likes to drink hot chocolate and lives in the Whispering Forest. On the occasion of his birthday, he organized a party for his friends with reindeer Chichotek and the bird Drobniaszek. Roll the dice and complete randomly drawn tasks on your way to Tappi's party.
Remember: it's all about fun here!

Purpose of the game: Get to Tappi's party as soon as possible!

Name: Миксология
Description:
This game is for 2-5 people and can be played by the whole family and company friends. The main thing before the game is delicious to eat, as it causes appetite.
Your goal is to get the most points, and for that you will need to collect from spices aromatic seasonings - mixes, prepare delicious dishes, and also discover countries where these spices grow.

Name: Dobellone
Description:
Northern Italian, set collection, card game similar to Scopa, but played with a special italian suits deck of 52 cards. Better with 4 players for a joint scoring tactics. The king card is wild, the ace can "clean" the cards on the table but not scoring a scopa, the deuce of swords is worth 1 point (Dobelon), also a Napoli sequence basically a set of ace, two and three or more of the same suit that could give a extra scoring points.

The pair of players reaching 120 points is declared winner.

Name: Shopping
Description:
Players play the role of characters who are handling money and shopping. There are stores with products and paths leading around them on the board placed at the center of the table. Each player starts the game with three coins.

The game has unique movement mechanic - player rolls a die with icons, move their figurine along any possible path, and stop at the first space with the same icon. They collect as many coins as they passed along the way. Then they can reveal and buy products adjacent to their position. If the die lands on a shopping cart, they can buy any of the opened products or roll again.

Because the products have different prices, the players have to balance getting and spending their coins.

The game ends when a player has five products in their shopping cart. Scoring - if a product has the icon of the player’s character or a star, it is worth two points, otherwise it is only worth one point. The player with the most points wins.

The game has an advanced mode included, in which players can close certain stores to block other players.

—description from the publisher

Name: Fighting Sail: Scenario Book 1 – Battle of Lissa: March 12, 1811
Description:
Battle of Lissa 
A naval action in 1811 between the British navy and the French Napoleonic navy. 
You get all the charts,ship data and information to fight a wooden ship action.

The rules Fighting Sail go along with the Scenario Book or use any other set to play.

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Rush M.D.: Maternity & Dental Clinics
Description:
Maternity & Dental Clinics is a new mini expansion for Rush M.D. that introduces two new modules which expand the game's Outpatient clinic.

In Maternity Clinic, you need to examine pregnant women to determine the gender of their baby(ies). In some cases the mother will have to be admitted in a Ward right away and have a surgery to give birth right away.

In order to identify each baby's gender or to determine if the pregnant ladies need to go into labor, you will need to perform an Ultrasound, in the same fashion that you perform this in the Ultrasound section of the new Examinations Board, by using the special see-through red plastic chip to locate one or more gender symbols on the back of the top Maternity Diagnosis card. For each symbol you locate, you must place the corresponding tile(s) on the mother's card. If instead of finding gender symbols during the ultrasound, you locate a scalpel symbol, this means that the mother-to-be needs to give birth immediately to ensure the health of her baby. You will need to Hospitalize the mother to a Ward bed and take her to an Operating Room soon! In the Operating Room you will need to bring a Doctor and a Nurse to deliver the baby!

In the Dental Clinic, you will get to admit Patients from the Outpatient Clinic who need to have their teeth checked up and cleaned. In order to perform a teeth cleanup, you will take the cubes and throw them like dice close by to the Dental Clinic board. Each cube(tooth) has one side that is colored black. Using your tweezers, you will need to place each tooth on the available slots of the Mouth tile but making sure that the black side of each tooth is facing down.

Name: The Hunters A.D. 2114: Hybrids
Description:
A group of unique and exceptionally brutal machines is making surprise attacks on local inhabitants. Who or what is responsible for this new threat? The characters unwittingly become entangled in a power play within the town and participate in ruthless clashes on the streets.
—description from the publisher

Hybrids, a third expansion for The Hunters A.D. 2114, includes a mission book with over 37 missions, 4 double-sided scenario tiles, 25 gear tokens, as well as over 300 event, road, town, location, and enemy cards.

Name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game – Read or Die: Challenge Scenario
Description:
The books and tomes found scattered across the Arkham Horror Files universe serve many purposes. Many offer vital and encyclopedic information, while others provide solace in a world beset by horror. But some books hold eldritch secrets contained within, and this dark knowledge may be enough to set the entire world off-kilter.

Read or Die is a special print-and-play challenge scenario for Arkham Horror: The Card Game designed to be played with Daisy Walker.

This scenario can be played as either a standalone scenario or as a side-story inserted into any campaign. In order to play this scenario, a copy of the Core Set, The Dunwich Legacy Deluxe Expansion, and the printed print-and-play files are required.

The print-and-play files are available here: https://www.fantasyflightgames.com/en/news/2020/5/5/beyond-our-dimension/

—description from the publisher
Families: Game: Arkham Horror – The Card Game
Game: Arkham Horror TCG – Challenge Scenarios & Parallel Investigators
Game: Arkham Horror TCG – The Dunwich Legacy
Series: Arkham Horror Files (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: Familiar Alchemy
Description:
The illustrious botanist Beira needs an apprentice! Will you and your familiar heed the call for a friendly competition of botany and brewing at her Highland Glasshouse? A wondrous world of plants, potions and familiars await in Familiar Alchemy, a semi-cooperative game rooted in Scottish folklore.

You and your friends will bond with cute and powerful Familiars to help channel your alchemical abilities and carefully select plants you want to include in your gardens. These plants can be grown and harvested for ingredients by taking a "Channel" or "Harvest" action on your turn.

Beira will set out a collection of Communal Brews that you will need to work together to complete, and a Communal Garden that you must tend. Each brew requires a different combination of ingredients. Taking the "Brew" action on your turn will allow you to add ingredients you have collected to one of the brews.

Your Familiar can also help you by turning unneeded ingredients into alchemical compost to speed up plant growth or by performing powerful alchemical rituals.

Once all Communal Brews are complete, you score points based on the number and type of ingredients you contributed and how well you looked after your plants. The one with the highest score will earn their place as Beira's Apprentice!

-description from designer

Name: Fighting Sail: Scenario Book 2 – Frigate Actions
Description:
Frigate Actions

Three scenarios include:

     Nymph vs cleopatre,
     Amazon vs Droits de l' Homme,
     Cleopatre vs Milan. 


all charts and data for ships are included.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Coal & Iron: Scenario Book 1 – The Battle of Lissa: 20 July 1866
Description:
Battle of Lissa - 20 July 1866

It has all the set ups for the battle between the French and British.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Coal & Iron: Scenario Book 2 – The Battle of the Yalu: 17 September 1894
Description:
Battle of Yalu River - 17 September 1894

A naval action between the Imperial Japanese and the Chinese in 1894 in China waters.

All the charts and ship data are included.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Sides of Steel: Scenario Book 1 – Tsushima: May 27, 1905
Description:
Tsushima - May 27, 1905 Pre-Dreadnought Scenario Book 1.

It has all the set ups for the battle between the Russians and Japanese War in Feburary 1904.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Hex Code
Description:
In Hex Code, players take the role of computer hackers competing to break into each others' computer the quickest. Each turn players hack their way into their target's firewall by placing shapes dependent on the roll of dice. Once the firewall grid has started to fill, players can start guessing their target's password. If the player's six-letter guess contains any characters in the correct position, the target must say so; however, if a player's guess shares similarities to their target's security layer or firewall code, they trigger a trap. The target can immediately connect a node on their microchip, eventually allowing them to discern individual letters in their target's password. Overload firewalls, rewire microchips, and catch people in security traps to guess your target's password and prove you're the fastest hacker around!

Hex Code is a free-to-play printable game designed during the COVID-19 crisis, and will remain available here and through the publisher's website forever, with continued support.

—description from the designer

Name: Sides of Steel: Scenario Book 2 – Yellow Sea: August 10, 1904
Description:
Yellow Sea - August 10, 1904 Pre-Dreadnought Scenario Book 2.

It has all the set ups for the battle between the Russians and Japanese War in August 1904.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Wybory 1919
Description:
January 1919. Poland returned to the map of Europe only two months earlier. Now the Republic desperately needs reforms which can be carried out only by Sejm. Even though the country doesn't even have its borders set up, the Chief of State calls for democratic election which will allow to choose the Representatives of the whole society. It's time for the first election campaign of the Second Polish Republic!

"Wybory 1919" is a dynamic boardgame in which the players are the leaders of four main political forces in the interwar Poland. They try to lead their parties to victory in the upcoming elections. By playing action cards, they compete for support in four main social groups: peasantry, city dwellers, workers and the minorities. They can increase their own popularity and place a supporter meeple in their color in one of the groups, decrease others' support, manipulate the regional elections' order or even cancel elections in some constituencies by calling in the military actions in the region. Each player gets an identical deck of 9 action cards at the start of the game, but draws up to the limit of three cards at random in their turn - reshuffling the discard pile if the draw pile runs out. Players need to strategize based on their current hand and pay attention to the cards that their opponents have already used.

Whoever gets the majority in each of the three groups favoured in the current round's constituency, wins the seat for their representative in that round of elections. The party that gets more representatives than any of the others after the last round is resolved, wins the game and assists in writing the Second Polish Republic's history!

The game was commissioned by the Social Communication Bureau at Chancellery of the Sejm of the Republic of Poland for the 100th anniversary of the first elections in Second Polish Republic. It's meant as an educational tool in teaching history and promotional item for the Sejm. As such, it hasn't been available in retail. The instructions booklet contains more detailed historical background on the elections of 1919-1920 in Poland. The action cards provide some basic information on the leaders of each political side as well as flavor texts in the form of newspaper quotes from that time.

Name: The Wizard of Oz
Description:
Join Dorothy, The Tinman, The Scarecrow and The Cowardly Lion as they follow the Yellow Brick Road in search of the Emerald City.

Players travel from Munchkinland searching for 12 hidden treasures: the witches hat, the hour glass, the magic wand, the ruby slippers, and more.
Can you remember where each and every one is hidden? When the mighty Wizard of Oz requests a treasure, the players race to be the first to find and deliver it to the Emerald City.

The first player to locate and deliver 3 treasures to Oz is the winner

—description from the back of the box (English edition)

This game is very close to Enchanted Forest. The differences are: It is only for up to four players. There are only 12 items to be searched. There are no trees but square card board tiles. The German rules text is mostly identical word by word to the original. However, no designers are mentioned. 
The German edition was published as a special commemorative edition on the occasion of a theater performance of "Der Zauberer von Oos".

—user summary

Name: Sides of Steel: Scenario Book 3 – Yalu River: 17 September 1894
Description:
Yalu River 17 September 1894

Pre-Dreadnought Scenario Book 3.

It has all the set ups for the battle between the Chinese and Japanese War in Feburary 1894.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Dreadnought: Scenario Book 1 – Dogger Bank: January 24, 1915
Description:
Dogger Bank - January 24, 1915
Book 1: It has all the set ups for the battle between the Germans and British War in January 1915.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Dreadnought: Scenario Book 2 – Coronel: November 1, 1914
Description:
Coronel - November 1, 1914
Book 2: It has all the set ups for the battle between the Germans and British War in November 1914.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Dreadnought: Scenario Book 3 – Plan Orange 1926
Description:
Plan Orange - 1926 

Book 3. It has all the set ups for the battle between the United States and Japanese in 1926.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship, and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Valeria: Card Kingdoms – Tsoukalos the Conspirator Promo Card
Description:
A promo card given away at conventions.

At the end of the game you score 1 VP for each gold, 2 VP for each Domain, and 1 VP for every 2 strength / magic.

—user summary

Edit : This card as been banish because of balance issue (too powerful)

Name: Dreadnought: Scenario Book 4 – Plan Black 1915
Description:
Plan Black 1915

Book 4. It has all the set ups for the battle between the United States and Germany around Puerto Rico in 1915.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship, and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Dreadnought: Scenario Book 5 – Plan Red 1915
Description:
Plan Red - 1915

Book 5. It has all the set ups for the war plan by US to intercept the British Fleet approaching from Canada.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship, and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Akihabara
Description:
It’s the 80s and the electric city in Tokyo start changing… players compete to open new stores around Akihabara station.

Players will have to build 5 building. On your turn, you have to draw biz cards that allow you to open the most interesting stores at the best building. Choosing the best floor will be the key to attract the customers, tourist and otakus.

Every time you draw a biz card, you have to decide to stop and get the biz cards and then arrange then on their building or continue by drawing more biz cards. Nevertheless, If you do so and draw two biz cards of the same type, your turn ends immediately and all the biz cards are discarded.

When playing a biz card on your building, you should to take account that is not allowed to play two cards of the same type on the same building.

The game ends when a player build the 5th floor of one of their buildings. Then, the rest of players will get one last turn.

Your final scoring will be as follows:
Check the first floor of your 5 building and get 1 VP per each type of biz you got. Then, do the same with the second floor and so on until you have scored all the floors. The player with the most points is the winner.

-description from designer

Name: Asking For A Friend
Description:
"Asking for a Friend: The party game that might get weird" is a party game where all players are both asking and answering a question each round. The official goal is to collect the most points over ten rounds of play. The real goal is to finally have an excuse to ask your friend's the questions you've never asked before.

At the start of a round, a question card is drawn that has a blank. (e.g. "How often do you _____?"). Each player writes a prompt on a piece of paper that fills in the blank to make a complete question (e.g. "wake up before your alarm", "cry", or "fart and blame it on someone else"). All the prompts get shuffled, and each player draws a prompt. Each player answers the prompt they drew (which is sometimes the one they wrote). After everyone has answered, a voting card is revealed and the players vote for the winning answer based on the criteria on the voting card. (One round the voting might be based on which answer is "Most likely to disappoint your parents" and the next round might be based on who gave the "Most wholesome answer"). The winning answer gets the voting card, which is worth a point. However, great answers are made in response to great questions. The author of the prompt that spurred the winning answer will receive a reward card. Then a new round begins.

If you don't want to answer a question, you can take a penalty card, but you might have to answer more questions later. Reward cards can do anything from telling someone else to get you a drink to letting you pick who answers which questions. Use your reward cards wisely, but don't forget to use them.

The game is concluded after 10 Question Cards/rounds have been completed (or really, however many you want to play!) The player with the most victory points is the winner.

The cards are minimalist and each deck has it's own color (white, black, and orange). There is nothing inherently dirty about this game, but you can make it very adult/mature if you'd like. You also could play with kids and grandparents at a family reunion and ask family friendly questions. The maturity level of the game depends on the prompts that are written.

Name: Riot at the Round Table
Description:
Camelot is in chaos, since King Arthur's throne is now up for the taking. Use your wits and arsenal to defeat your foes.

To begin the riot, you attack the defender with a card(s) from your hand. Other players can always join the attack by playing any matching valued cards. The defender can flee, pass, or attempt to be victorious by defeating all the cards. If your friend is about to triumph, you can play another card at the last minute. Will it be enough to push him over the edge?

Using an arsenal card or a jester card can greatly effect the course of each round. Successfully defeat cards to earn more arsenal cards. Throughout the game, you can also earn crowns and scepters to help you in your quest to become the new ruler of Camelot. Three crowns wins you the game! Do you have the strength to be victorious? Join the riot and we shall see!

—description from the publisher

Name: Task Force: Scenario Book 1 – Plan Orange 1936
Description:
Plan Orange - 1936
Book 1. It has all the set ups for the battle between the United States and Japanese in 1936.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Task Force: Scenario Book 2 – Invasion of Malta 1942
Description:
Invasion of Malta 1942
Book 2. It has all the set ups for the Invasion of Malta in 1942 between the British and Italians.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Task Force: Scenario Book 3 – Malaya 1936
Description:
Malaya 1936

Book 3. It has all the set ups for the battle between the British and Japanese War in 1936.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Task Force: Scenario Book 4 – PQ 27.3: Convoy Battle in the North Atlantic
Description:
PQ 27.3 - Convoy Battle in the North Atlantic

Book 4. It has all the set ups for the Convey Battle in the North Alantic in 1942.

It comes complete with all the British and German ships that fought in the battle,damage charts for each ship,and notes and rules modifications for the battle.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Pocket Innovation
Description:
Pocket Innovation is a card layering civilization game using 40 cards.

Each card represents innovative inventions and discoveries.
Players lay these cards to develop their own civilization.
You need to lay cards clever or you will fall behind in the flow of innovations!
You win if you have most victory points at the end of a game.

You can also play solo.
In solo, you play against Napoleon, a mighty imaginary player.

Name: Welcome To...: Quack
Description:
Two families of ducks are lost in the streets of your city! Please, bring back the ducklings to their parents!

This is a free PnP expansion for Welcome to..., available to all in these troubled times.

The expansion contains a sheet with a new twist, 3 City Plan cards and both multiplayer and solo rules (Classic & New Solo Mode).

-description from designer

Name: Mars Rover
Description:
Mars Rover is a solitaire game of Mars exploration. You control a robotic Mars rover across the surface of Mars. Your mission is to collect soil samples and upload the analysed data. You have a three-day deadline and need to contend with the harsh Martian environment, solar flares and marsquakes.

The game is card-driven by a single deck of cards with the status of your rover updated on a game playmat. During the game you will be regularly draw a card from the explore deck and a single element on the card will determine an outcome or provide event relevant information. Each game has a soil data upload target. During your exploration of the Martian terrain you will have to balance energy use for exploration, drilling for soil samples, uploading data and navigating away from rockslides.

Your mission is limited to three days and when you decide to end the day you can repair and recharge your rover. There are, however, opportunities for energy recharging during the day and a push-your-luck mechanism when considering whether to explore further or stop for the day.

The game ends on day 3 and winning is determined on whether you have met your soil data upload target and made it back to base. If your rover ever has 0% energy across drill, gyroscope and battery power, your rover is powerless on Mars and your mission has failed.

—description from the publisher

Name: Color City
Description:
2 groups are fighting for the domination of Color City. Color City is represented by a grid in the center of the game board. The youngest player starts the game and the players take turns playing until the end of the game.

Each turn is divided in 5 steps:

1) Explore

     The player pitches one of the cubes of his HQ, with one of these fingers, towards the city.


2) Power activation (optional action)

     Once during each game, each team can decide to use the power of their gang.
     To do this, the team checks its power box and applies its effect.
     Once checked, a power box can no longer be checked during the rest of the game.
     Power of the green gang - Lucky Day: allows you to take back the cube pitched this turn, replace it on its HQ and p it again.
     Purple gang power - Purple Pain: allows you to destroy one of the cubes located in an opposing HQ.


3) Fight

     If the cube stops outside the city, it is destroyed.
     We consider that a cube stops on an area as soon as it covers 1 mm of its surface.
     A destroyed cube is placed in the game box and can no longer be used for the rest of the game.


4) Conquer

     If the cube has not been destroyed, color the area on which it stopped with your marker and then take the cube back.
     When you take one of your cubes back, put it on your HQ.
     The city is made up of 81 squares. If a cube covers several boxes, color all of these boxes.


5) Victory check and End of turn.

     If no player has won or lost the game, his opponent plays.


End conditions:

A) If a player succeeds in forming a horizontal or vertical line of 9 spaces with his color, he wins the game.

     Diagonal lines do not count.



B) If a player succeeds in forming a square of 16 boxes (4 x 4 boxes) with his color, he wins the game.

C) If a player succeeds in eliminating his opponent's 4 cubes, he wins the game.

     Reminder: cubes are destroyed when they stop in an area they must not occupy.


—description from the designer

Name: Brittany 1944: The Race for Brest
Description:
Solo game, based on Race to the Rhine mechanics, simulating the liberation of Brittany during August and September '44.
The 8th US Corps of Troy Middleton has the mission to liberate the region and secure the Breton ports for use them as supply bases.
The player commands the 4 divisions of the 8th US Corps and his task is, in a limited time to score a maximum of Medals, by destroying German units, occupying strategic cities, besieging and capturing the ports and preventing their destruction by the Wehrmacht.

Name: Ральф против интернета
Description:
Ralph got out of the game machine and now walks on the Internet! Is there enough space on the Web for such a big guy? Check the strength of the World Wide Web servers along with the characters in the Disney animated film "Ralph Breaks the Internet". The one who overloads the most servers will be the winner.

In the deck of cards are four characters + a joker (replaces any character) with numbers from 1 to 16. At the beginning, 12 cards are dealt to each. In each round, you must select one card face up. Then all the cards are laid out in descending order on the table. If your card is the fourth in a row, column or pile - you take it. These are your victory points. After 12 rounds, the player with the most points is declared the winner.

—description from the publisher

Name: Imperial Bayonets: We Were Not Cowards – Sedan 1870
Description:
"Imperial Bayonets: We Were Not Cowards - Sedan 1870" is an operational wargame simulation of the last battle of the Second Empire. It uses a rules-engine heavily inspired by The Library of Napoleonic Battles rules system by the illustrious Kevin Zucker and OSG. Several scenarios allow for a quicker French response to Prussian maneuvers the day before creating a salvageable situation for the French. Each hex is approximately 1KM and units are divisions which can break down into their subordinate brigades. Maintaining a chain of command allows players to freely act with their units, while units outside of command range must rely on initiative. Special rules are included for French Chassepot and Mitrailleuse and the obliterating power of Prussian Krupp artillery.

This is our first wargame outside of the 2140 series and is the first of several efforts to see games our heroic CEO designed a few years ago that have sat languishing among other ideas, priorities and projects. This will include a 22x34” map, 560 half inch counters, several player aids along with a rule-book and 2d6.

Name: Bacterium
Description:
Bacterium is a free PNP territory-control game for two Players. You each represent different strains of bacteria, bred in a lab, which are competing to spread widely into as many Petri dishes as possible. But beware of the Penicillin mold floating in the air...

To play this game you will need:
This rule set
A 6x6 grid map
A sheet of game counters, but you can substitute poker chips, coins, buttons, beads, marbles, or any other game pieces of two different colors as Player pieces, plus 6 additional pieces of another color as Penicillin markers
1d6

Each Player starts by placing one game piece anywhere on the board. Players then place new game pieces on the board. They may choose to do this in one of two ways: they may place a single game piece anywhere on the board. Or they may make a “trail” by following any straight-line path from one of their already-placed game pieces (as a Bacterium, after all, you want to spread yourself as far as you can.) The Player then "reproduces" by placing his pieces in each empty spot in between along the three-space trail, reflecting the rapid growth of the bacteria. Every Petri dish game space he has thereby infected then becomes a potential source for further infections.

In addition to moving, game pieces can be captured by surrounding a Bacterium and starving it of resources so it dies and is replaced by the Player's Bacteria.

In addition, there are Penicillin Spores that are floating around in the lab which will land randomly, killing the Bacteria in some Petri dishes and replacing them. Every so often, Players roll dice to determine where the Penicillin has landed. If there are any Bacteria game pieces in these marked spaces, they are removed and replaced with an Opponent’s game piece.

Play continues until neither Player is able to make a legal move. The Player whose Bacteria occupy the most Petri dishes at the end of the game, is the winner.

—description from the designer

Name: Dr. Biscuits' Radical Road Trip: 60 Fun Games to Play in Your Car
Description:
60 Fantastic Games To Play in Your Car!


     Survive a License Plate Asteroid Field
     Play a new version of H-O-R-S-E using the radio
     Spot themed bumper stickers for Points
     Spark a dance contest at the next rest stop
     Send a postcard to the White House (included!)
     Trick your friends into meowing like a cat
     Play games like Duck Duck Bruce, Flip Dingus, and Ronjon Chico Bonbon … And that’s just scratching the surface!


Dr. Biscuits' Radical Road Trip is the brainchild of Barry and Jason, the creators of Game Night in a Can. Just as they did with their first successful game, Barry and Jason used their comedic skills and fun-loving competitive spirit to create 60 brand new games to play in the car. There are 6 categories of games to choose from, each one containing 10 games. The Categories are Everlasting Games, Logical Games, Ridiculous Games, Games for Humanity, Creative Games and Games Outside the Car. It's been called "Cranium for the Car" by some and "the most fun I've had in a car since you were conceived" by others

—description from the publisher

Name: D6: It Takes A Village
Description:
Grow Your Village... with this expansion to D6.
Now you can have three more classes to choose from. DO you need a card? Draw it from one of the three handy-dandy card carts. Did you slay a monster? Collect your two coins from the Village coin tray. Want to raise your stats? Now you can drink from the actual Fountain of You.
A glorious hunter deserves a glorious Village!

—description from the publisher

Name: Dragondado
Description:
With Dragondado children and adults have fun while working on their concentration, reflex-speed, emotional self control, fine motor skills and math abilities.

A compelling board game in which participants will have to compete against each other to complete 14 mathematical mental calculation tournaments with speed and dexterity in the shortest time possible!

After training in each of the 14 challenges, players can challenge each other in the Knights Arena to find out who the Dragondado Knight will be.

Name: Tactoo
Description:
Every year in the Kingdom of Ludus there is a festival dedicated to fairy tales. But this year, during the night, some strange elements entered the stories, completely changing their meaning. Can you find these items? To do this, players will have to rely on their sense of touch, find the intruder and put the fairy tales in the correct order.

Tactoo encourages tactile, manual and attention skills.

Name: The Korner'D Challenge
Description:
Pick a side of the game board - colors or animals - and then pass out the tiles to each player. Ready? Set? MATCH!

It's a race to match all of your tiles with the colors or animals on the game board. But here's the catch - Each tile only matches with one specific space on the game board.

Name: Schmuggler
Description:
The smuggler has to go from his Island hideout to the four harbors and back again to win the game. The four police boats try to capture the smuggler. Movement is determined by a die. A change of direction while moving is allowed. If the smuggler lands on a police boat, it has to return to one of the harbors for repair. If a police boat lands on the smuggler, the game ends and the police player wins.

—user summary

Name: Paintbrush
Description:
Paintbrush is a deeply strategic game coming soon the Blinks Game System. Paintbrush, like all great strategy games, uses simple mechanics to create complex situations, all made possible by Blinks, the world's first smart tabletop game system. AI-powered game pieces act as both brush and canvas, and players take turns rearranging the dynamic pieces to spread their color onto as many blank canvasses as they can. Simple mechanics mean the game can be picked up easily, but the strategic depth allows for repeated play and the possibility of mastery.

Paintbrush is a game for 2 to 6 players, played with 6 or more Blinks. A typical game of Paintbrush can take anywhere from 15 to 30 minutes, with larger player counts and more Blinks often leading to longer games. Each player selects a unique Paintbrush color, and take turns moving individual Blinks around the board to spread their color onto blank canvasses. A canvas which has been painted entirely with one color becomes a Paintbrush itself. Once all the Blinks have been converted to Paintbrushes, the game is over, and whichever player has the most Paintbrushes wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Raid
Description:
Raid, the newest game on the Blinks Game System, places you in command of a viking horde, competing with other players to grab as much territory as you can. It's an intense game of strategy and prediction, as each player secretly inputs orders into the AI-powered Blinks game pieces, then watches as skirmishes play out in real time. It's the kind of unique analog/digital hybrid experience that's only possible on Blinks, the world's first smart tabletop game system. The game started as a post on the Move38 developer forum in early February, and has since been iterated on and perfected with the help of the Move38 team.

In Raid, 2 to 4 players compete to conquer an island made of Blinks. The game requires at least 6 Blinks, and takes 10-20 minutes, depending on the size of the island and number of players. Each round, players close their eyes, then take turns opening their eyes and making an attack on the island with their longboat. Once all players have attack, all eyes are opened and the game calculates the outcome of the round. Armies spread from the coast into the center of the island, competing for a dwindling set of unoccupied territories. When all coastal territories have been attacked and no more longships can land, the game calculates which player conquered the largest territory, making them the winner.

—description from the publisher

Name: Group Therapy
Description:
Can't we all just get along?! It's your job to get these Blinks what they need most: extroverts want neighbors, introverts need their space.  It's a focused frenzy for one or many!

The Pieces display their preferred state and players have a short time window to separate pieces. Each round is different and the modular board allows before wild configurations.

This game really shines as a cooperative challenge to sort pieces in time leaving no piece behind.

Name: in the mood
Description:
in the mood is the second game from Stefan Breuer (head of youth welfare in Dorsten/Germany) which is offered for free download to the people during corona-pandemic. 
The city of Dorsten wants to bring some fun for youth and families. The game can be played pnp and in videomeetings and so on.

in the mood is a partygame about music and emotions. What do you think about "Highway to hell" during a candle-light-dinner? Fits perfect, is okay oder never ever?!?
Can the other players imagine what you do feel?

—description from the designer

in the mood ist das zweite Spiel von Stefan Breuer (Jugendamtsleiter Dorsten), das umsonst zum Download den Menschen während der Corona-Pandemie geschenkt wird. Die Stad Dorsten will den Jugendlichen und Familien etwas Spaß vermitteln. Das Spiel kann als pnp zu Hause gespielt werden, aber auch in Videomeetings.
in the mood ist ein Partyspiel über Musik und Emotionen. Was denkst du über "Highway to hell" beim Candlelight-Dinner? Passt perfekt, ist okay oder geht gar nicht?!?
Werden die anderen Spieler erraten können, was du fühlst?

—description from the designer (German)

Name: The Battle of France 1940
Description:
The Battle of France was the first great tank battle, and perhaps the first major battle, of World War II. Of course, it was not called that at the time. People called it ‘Hitler’s War’ or ‘The Phony War’. Perhaps it was Hitler’s war, but it was far from phony. It was, in fact, the complete opposite and the Wehrmacht was out to prove it. France was to be the proving grounds that Germany’s Panzer tank divisions were to become feared on.

No one suspected a strategic pincer attack from the Ardennes forest, but rather through the Maginot Line. Nearly everyone believed that the Maginot Line would be the ultimate wall of defense against Germany. Heinz Guderian was the exception. His ground breaking idea of mechanized warfare created World War II. Here is where he would show the world the strength of a concentrated attack force and how an entire nation could be brought to its knees by a swift, decisive strike.

In Battle of France 1940 you play the role of either Guiderian or Charles De Gaulle. You make the decisions; Will you attack Dunkerk and cut off the British? Can you defend Paris against the ever growing German armies? Will your men continue to fight despite massive casualties and declining morale? How will you deal with supply shortages?

Combat cards simulate fog of war and new challenges to face your troops every round. Unique rules mimic the Blitzkrieg system of warfare and special combat features include divisional singularity, tank superiority, air support and retreat rules. Also featuring special territories showcasing the historic elements of the Ardennes Forest and the Maginot Line.

Battle of France 1940 is filled with factors beyond your control. However, the heart of the game is in how you position your forces so that the industry, morale and equipment of your opponent is destroyed, captured or commandeered.

Can you shape the fate of the world in a few short hours?

—description from the designer

Name: Defiant
Description:
The floating tribes of Typatia have lived under the tyrannical rule of The Empress for far too long. She has starved the people, abused the dinosaurs, and grown fat off the riches of the land.

As a Chief of Typatia, it is your duty to throw off the yoke of oppression and claim your tribe's rightful place as the leaders of Typatia.

Will you do this through economic prowess, scientific advancement, political negotiation, or pure military might? The choice is yours as you spread your influence across the floating lands.

Defiant is a 4X bag-building game set in a land of floating islands and battling dinosaurs.

Each turn you will use the cubes you drew (at the end of the previous turn) to activate actions. Each action requires 2 cubes and will increase in power if you are willing to spend your rare bronze, silver, or even gold cube to complete the action. Be sure to plan ahead or your previously placed cubes could end up wasted.

Air battles occur when 2 sets of flyers encounter each other. Transported raptors & rexes add nothing to these battles. Only the number & strength of each army's flyers matter. If the attacking flyers win, they may then drop their land units onto the island below.

These dropped units will then instigate a land battle if defenders are present. These battles are more tricky, with secret modifier cards influencing each side's strength.

A player may be strong in the air, but weak on land, unable to take over defended islands. Or a player may be strong on land, but weak in the air, unable to transport their raptors and rexes to new islands.

The game ends when a player has completed enough objectives. These include:
•Completing 1 of the 4 upgrade tracks.
•Winning an air battle.
•Winning a land battle.
•Defeating the Empress.
•Completing the special objective which is drawn at the beginning of the game.

Players then count up the points from their objectives, controlled hexes, and gold/silver/bronze cubes.

Defiant comes from our love of bag-building and 4X games. We aimed to build a 4X game that could be played quicker than a normal 4X game, yet still have the same scope and feel. The bag building element helps in this endeavor, as players can be planning their turns from 1 turn to the next (since they've already drawn the next turn's cubes).

Note: Hardcore 4X gamers can choose to play to a higher objective thresh-hold for an even more sprawling and vast game of Defiant.

-description from designer

Name: Who's Got the Baby? Card Game
Description:
Who’s Got the Baby is a card game with a fun twist on the Mardi Gras King Cake baby tradition!

Mardi Gras season means lots of King Cakes and trying to find the Baby inside! Although the Baby symbolizes luck to whoever finds it in their slice of king cake, the downside for them is that they are responsible for purchasing the next king cake and throwing the next Mardi Gras party! That downside is why you don’t want to be the one stuck with the baby in this game! The last player left in the game and not eliminated by the King Cake Baby card wins! Your turn consists of two steps: playing as many Action cards as you want and then drawing a card from the Draw pile to end your turn. After your turn ends, the next person can go by playing Action cards first and then drawing a card to end their turn. Playing Action Cards in the game such as Fortune Teller, Bead Throw Attack, and the Crawfish Block help you avoid the Baby in the Draw pile at all costs! That’s it! Last person standing wins the game! The key is to avoid those Baby Game Over cards! Who’s got the baby? Hopefully, not you!

Includes: 54 cards, box, and instructions.

Name: 1916: The WWI Card Game
Description:
The horrors of trench warfare rage across Europe in 1916. Machine guns are cutting brave soldiers to ribbons when they go "over the top" and are confronted with mazes of wire. Tanks are appearing more frequently on the battlefield, as well as biplanes which seem to evolve every day. The major source of havoc, however, is artillery, which rains hell from above on a regular basis. Not to mention the poison gas.

1916: The Card Game is a tense filler for two players, and includes all of the above. The rules are simple, but the choices aren't. Players represent the opposing commanders of a small stretch of trench line. They draw and play cards from a common deck, but some can only be used by one side. Some cards can be played alone or in combination, and what to play and what to hold in hand can be critical decisions. Some cards have multiple uses. Biplanes, for example, can be used for recon, assault support, or aerial intercept. Victory can be total, major, minor or, rarely, the result can be a stalemate.

-description from designer

Name: Crimson Company: Ragnarok
Description:
The Ragnarok expansion adds a set of viking-themed sellswords to the game. Among them are a number of "norse god" cards that feature the new "passive" keyword and add their own unique rules and twists to the battlefield whenever they're in play.

In Crimson Company, two opposing players take on the roles of adventurous noblemen in a cut-throat fantasy world. In a battle of wits, they assemble armies of sellswords, from hardened warriors and shady merchants to mythical creatures as old as time.

Your goal in a match of Crimson Company is to conquer two of the three castles in the center. You conquer a castle by amassing more strength than your opponent in the castle's lane by the time that lane is scored. A lane is scored once a player owns at least four cards in it.

Cards represent a large variety of characters, all of which have specific strength values and unique effects. The latter are either one-time instant effects that happen when a card is played, or they are triggered in specific phases of the game. Four randomly drawn cards from the character deck are "on offer". You may bid coins on only one of those at a time. Then your opponent decides to either pay you off, doubling the coins you bid, or pass and let you play the card.

-description from designer

Name: Harpoon Player's Handbook: 5th Edition
Description: The Harpoon Player's Handbook is a compilation of all the charts and tables contained in the rulebook. Use of this playing aid greatly assists the flow of play in multiple player games, as all of the data is right at hand, along with references to the appropriate section of the rulebook.

Name: Gamot
Description:
“Before you looms the dimly lit entrance of the most feared dungeon in the land. It is called the GAMOT. Within the Gamot lie dangers untold, for no hero has yet returned from its deep depths. The journey here has not been an easy one. You dismount from your trusty steed and ready your sword and shield. If you conquer the Gamot, you will earn the greatest glory in the land and with it a place among the King’s personal guard. A worthy position for a hero such as yourself!

As you approach the entrance to the Gamot, you can smell the foul stench of death and are overcome with an unexplained dread. While you steel your nerves against this dark air, you hear the sound of hoof beats behind you. Your horse has fled in fear… You are truly alone now. You step into the entrance of the Gamot, filled with determination. As you do so, however, the floor gives way and you find yourself suddenly tumbling down an incline. You hit the ground below with a hard thud. After taking a moment to regain your bearings, you search in the darkness for your sword and shield. They are nowhere to be found! Rising to your feet, you see that you have fallen into a long corridor lined with doors. A haunting laugh echoes in the dungeon. The only thing that stands between you and whatever horrors await you in the dungeon is your will to live and your desire to prove yourself the greatest hero in the land…

Will you survive the Gamot?”

Gamot is a solitaire dungeon crawling card game, designed to be quick and playable on-the-go. You take the role of an adventuring hero as you attempt to navigate the perils of the dungeon. You will search for weapons and items in which to defend yourself, while fighting fearsome monsters and drinking potions to keep your health up! No two games are ever the same!


     Arm yourself with swords, bows and warhammers, or locate powerful weapons such as the Golden Trident!
     Use special items like the Magic Ring to rearrange the shape of the dungeon!
     Choose wisely when to face a threat head on and when to run!
     Face monsters such as werewolves, black knights, great worms and the dreaded and deadly lich!
     Search the halls of the dungeons for potions to help you recover from your wounds suffered at the hands of these brutal beasts!



Gamot is the perfect game for on-the-go players! Gamot requires little space to play, plays as quickly as you can make decisions and can be carried in your pocket. Designed to be played while waiting in lines, travelling on buses or trains, or on your break at work, Gamot also works for filling in time while you wait for your turn at the gaming table. With only a deck of 54 standard playing cards (and some small counters that you can easily replace with your memory or a scrap of paper and a pencil), and developed to appeal to both your mind and your wallet, Gamot provides a great and inexpensive dungeon crawling experience that won't break the bank!

Gamot is easily learned, but tough to master. Gamot is also family-friendly, and requires only basic math skills to get started.

—description from the designer

Name: Task Force: Scenario Book 5 – Battleships at Midway
Description:
Battleships at Midway

It has all the set ups for the battle between the Americans and Japanese ships at Midway in 1942.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship, and notes and rules modifications for the battle.

This Scenario Book uses the Rules Task Force or you can use another set of rules that you like.
Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Description:
Battleships at Leyte Gulf

It has all the set ups for the battle of Leyte between the Americans and Japanese in 1944.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship, and notes and rules modifications for the battle.

Description:
Battle of Bizerte 1940 - The Franco-Italian War of 1940

It has all the set ups for the battle between the Italians and French in 1940.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship, and notes and rules modifications for the battle.

Families: Series: Fast Play Naval Rules (Small War Games)

Name: Autumn Grove Manor
Description:
Autumn Grove Manor is a co-op game for 2-6 players. A team of ghost hunters, armed with only Lord Latimer's Journal, must collect 6 gems which can be combined to create a 'weapon' to defeat Palmershu, the Demon God, who has claimed the manor as his own. You'll have to exorcise the ghosts, while avoiding holes in the ground and searching the manor for items and gems, but beware, Palmershu may appear at the end of any round, and he's not pleased that you're trying to exorcise him.

The game is set up by shuffling the room cards, placing them upside down on the board so each room can't be seen and placing all the players at the front door and all the ghosts and the Palmershu marker are placed in the cloth bag.
During Part 1 A player has 8 action points each turn, which can be used for moving, exorcising ghosts, using items, giving an item to an ally, or opening chests or doors. Once a player opens either a chest or a door, they've alerted the ghosts to their presence and their turn immediately ends and they turn over a card from the ghost deck.
During the end of turn players must add more ghosts onto the board using a pair of D20 dice pulling ghosts (or Palmershu) randomly from the bag.
The aim of Part 1 is to search the house for 6 gems, spread across the house in the different rooms.

In Part 2 the board is flipped and Palmershu starts his final attack as the team attempt to destroy him. 
All the items you've collected in part 1 are carried over and can be played any round before anyone rolls to attack. The number of gems you collected will decreases the number of cards revealed for where Palmershu will appear.

Part 2 is split into 5 sections:
Palmershu's Arrival
From the Palmershu Deck reveal the correct number of card (the more gems you found in Part 1, the less places he may attack from)
Character Actions
The Characters can then use items and move up to 3 spaces in any order.
Palmershu Appears
The top card of Palmershu's attack deck is revealed which reveals which card and which power is used.
Characters Attack
The Characters who are in range of Palmershu or ghosts then attack them.
Palmershu Attacks
Finally the ghosts and Palmershu will attack the Characters.

To win the game the team must defeat Palmershu. However if all the ghosts are removed from the bag then the team must flee the house and the game is lost, or if any player loses all their hearts then the game is lost.
There are 4 levels of difficulty, which vary the number of ghosts on the board to begin and the number that appear each turn.

—description from the designer

Name: Biplane Barmy: Refuelled Edition
Description:
Biplane Barmy Refuelled is the long awaited second edition of Biplane Barmy, the game of World War I fighter combat.

It uses the same core "choose & move" system but is the first choose and move game based on a hexagonal map.

Players control one or more planes each and secretly choose maneuvers each turn, then move all planes simultaneously and resolve firing.

The game is fast and furious, typically playable in around 15 minutes, making it ideal to fill on round a roleplaying session or as a tournament game.

The game uses simple mechanics for fast play, but doesn't sacrifice detail with stats for a wide range of aircraft and rules to handle all manner of specifics, from bombing to garros wedges.

—description from the publisher

Name: I'm Not Saying You're Stupid...
Description:
I'm Not Saying You're Stupid... is a trivia game where players try to guess the right answer, but also guess which player has the most wrong answer.

The game contains 110 trivia cards with 4 questions on each card. It also contains 9 I'm Not Saying You're Stupid... cards.

At the beginning of the game each player gets paper and a pen to write their answers on. Also one player is designated as the score keeper. Each player also gets one of the I'm Not Saying You're Stupid...  cards.

To start one player draws a trivia card and reads the first question. Each player writes what they think the answer is. All of the questions have a numeric answer, and each player should only write a numeric answer. After every player has written their answer, each player places their  I'm Not Saying You're Stupid...  cards in front of the player whose answer they think is furthest from the true answer. Then the answer is revealed and players score points. 5 points for the correct answer, 2 points for the closest answer, and 1 point for placing the  I'm Not Saying You're Stupid... in front of the player who had the answer furthest from the correct answer. After scoring the next question is read. When all the questions are read from one card, the next player draws the next card. The game continues until one player reaches a predetermined amount of points or a predetermined amount of time has passed.

Name: What If, But Also
Description:
What If, But Also is a lighthearted party game in which 4 or more players compete to spin stories out of chaos and pull creative pitches out of wacky prompts — all to win the judge’s favor.

Each round, players come up with the best possible or worst possible scenario, based on the cards in play and in their hands. Scenarios are inspired by (however loosely players want), and must reference, a phrase created by 5 cards: 2 Link Cards and 3 Story Cards. These cards change between rounds.

Each turn, one player takes on the role of judge and all other players take on the role of storytellers. The judge determines whether they want to hear the best or worst possible scenario and indicate by flipping the "What If…" card to its positive or negative side. They draw the top two cards of the Link deck and play them face up. They then play a Story card from their own hand to begin the scenario. Storytellers play Story cards from their hands to supply options for 2 of the words in the phrase. These 2 words are different for each storyteller, meaning they’ll base their scenarios off slightly different phrases.

At the end of the turn, roles shift. The player to the left of the previous judge becomes the new judge. Each turn consists of three phases: judge’s setup, storyteller’s scenarios, and judge’s choice. Play continues until every player has had a chance to be judge twice — or keep going as long as you want! The game can be ended after any judge’s choice phase.

—description from the publisher

Name: Bluff the Bullet
Description:
Bluff the Bullet is a poker-like game, with extra elements of bluffing and special card abilities. Players are dealt two separate hands, a “Scoring Hand” that determines if they win or lose, and a “Playing Hand,” whose cards have abilities that they can use to help improve their Scoring Hands.

At the start of the game, players are dealt five-card Scoring Hands, and are competing to have the best hand at the end of each round. But there’s one problem: While they start the game knowing what their cards are, that can change. Players are also dealt Playing Hands. During the game they will use abilities on these Playing Hand cards to learn about and change their and others’ Scoring Hands, to try to give themselves the best Scoring Hand possible.

Scoring Hands are ranked similarly (but not exactly) like poker, because each card has one of six suits and number value (from 1 to 7). The number values are important for scoring. Each card also has an ability based on its suit. When you use an ability, state which card(s) its ability is targeting. All abilities (except for bullets) affect Scoring Hand cards.

Beginning with the starting player and proceeding in clockwise order, each player takes a turn playing one card from their Playing Hand. The round ends when no one has any cards left to play. On your turn, must play a card, unless you’ve played a bullet card between your last turn and this one. In that case, you may still play a Playing Hand card, but it is optional. Whoever has the highest Scoring Hand at the end of the game is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Name: Task Force: Scenario Book 8 – Small Gun Action I
Description:
Small Gun Action I

It has all the set ups for the battle between the British and Germans in World War II.

It comes complete with all the ships that fought in the battle, damage charts for each ship, and notes and rules modifications for the battle.

This Scenario Book uses the Rules Task Force or you can use another set of rules that you like.

Name: Task Force: Scenario Book 13 – Coral Sea: 4-8 May 1942
Description:
Coral Sea - 4-8 May 1942
This scenario book contains all charts and ship data to fight the Coral Sea action.

It also has aircraft rules and carriers with aircraft on them.
It comes with a with a grid pattern so you can search for the other player.
